fields.headline: My first boss
fields.bodyText: TV presenter Hippo was my first TV programme and its producer, Martin Everard, was my first boss. My father knew him at the BBC. I'd just come out of Guildford School of Acting and my father mentioned that Martin had left the BBC to start up a 'super channel' - a satellite station. This was in the days when satellite TV was completely new. I wondered if it might be a way to get my equity card . At the time I was sending off my CV to theatres up and down the country and I hadn't thought of going straight to television. So I wrote a letter saying, "Dear Martin, you know my father, and I wondered if I could come for an audition if you are making any children's programmes." I wanted to be a children's TV presenter and actress. Go off and video yourself with kids, he wrote back. They were looking for someone to present a daily kids' show. I called up my old school, King Alfred's, and asked if they'd let me film with the kids. I'd always loved being around youngsters. I played a few games and sent the video in and a week later Martin called. He was a lovely man and offered me my own daily children's programme, which I hosted for one year. Martin gave me that opportunity. He looked after me totally - he sort of held my hand. I was very green and I had a lot to learn. There was just me, a producer and an assistant and we used to put out five hours a week. There was a great buzz - it felt like we were pioneering something new and fresh. We had a great Christmas party. I realised, then, that people in television could really drink. We all got so drunk. But Martin was a lovely, kind man and he is still in TV. I went to his 60th birthday party recently. I always thank him - he enabled me to fulfil my dream. It's vital to chase your dream - don't sit still, waiting for something to happen. Gaby Roslin stars in Dinner, a National Theatre production, touring theatres in June and July. ·anstead.writing@ntlworld.com
